First AA, AAA, AAAA, C & D are not batteries. They are cells. A battery has more that one cell. Most cells (non rechargeable) are 1.5 volts, so both the D "old man" train and the AAAA train have the same voltage and I suspect the same strength of magnetic field but the AAAA is a light sports car and the D is a heavy bus.

Anything called a battery that has a voltage greater than 1.5 volts is usually REALLY a battery. If you break open a 9V battery you will find 6 AAAA cells inside. A car battery actually has Six 2V cells (lead acid is different that flashlight batteries).

Even though the D and the AAAA have the same voltage, The D has more energy so the old man train will run much longer unless something breaks.

Some camera batteries are 6 volts (open them up and you'll find 4 watch cells inside) and still smaller than a C cell. Maybe smaller than a AA cell.

Lastly, a watch cell is still 1.5 volts and VERY light. Though the smaller number of coils in play may counteract this.

In the original videos, the front & rear magnets actually had opposite orientations. Either both north poles or both south poles pointing out. I think that with more than two magnets you would have to keep alternating them, NS SN NS

To elaborate, there is no positive electron. That is a 'virtual effect'. Kind of like how one would say a vacuum sucks, but really, the atmosphere is pushing you.

This doesn't mean the positive side is the 'safe side', actually, the opposite. The positive side represents the 'potential' side, the negative side is simply the electron source, and the potential is like a 'vacuum' for the electrons. When 'ground' is the electron source, that means YOU could be the electron source, which is why the positive side shocks you, even though YOU are the one supplying the electrons for the circuit.

My hypothesis is that the cylindrical magnets should work better because they make more contact with the coil, so there is better electrical coupling. And also the cylindrical battery would be physically supported by more windings of the coil instead of bumping from winding to winding, falling a little in between each. Granted, too long of a cylindrical magnet would increase friction enough to loose the benefits of not falling between coils.

I'm not surprised that the C-cell battery moved slowly. C, A, AA, and AAA batteries all have the same electric potential (V), 1.5V. The larger batteries just store more charge and can run longer. Since the resistance (R) of the electrical connection between the magnets and copper coils is roughly the same for all batteries and you're applying the same voltage, you should drive the same current (I = V/R). The magnetic field that pushes the train along is directly proportional to the current (B ~ I). SO, same voltage means same applied force, but since the battery is heavier it moves more slowly.

If you want it to go faster, try a higher voltage or lighter battery or reducing the resistance (which will be tough with household parts). Great video and at-home experiment!

I think it works because of Fleming's left hand rule.
When current flows in a wire, and an external magnetic field is applied across that flow, the wire experiences a force perpendicular both to that field and to the direction of the current flow.
Nothing to do with slight differences in flux or whatever.

The AAA batteries and C batteries have the same voltage, so they have the same force. However the C battery has more mass so it can't move as fast. Hence the smaller AAAA battery goes faster. Of course, the C battery has a larger capacity so it should run for longer before dying.

Running batteries in sequence increases the voltage so they have more force, but it's also not perfect because you are also increasing the mass. But if you found a battery with a larger voltage it should move faster.

Your magnetic field diagrams are not very helpful. The right hand rule might help.
The force applied to a magnetic field is at right angles to the current and also at right angles to the magnetic field.
The direction of the current is pretty clear, between the two contact points.
It is through the coils that surround the battery, between the contact points, and no where else.
So the field around the outer ends of the magnets has no current to react against.

But the two like poles, pointing flux toward the battery
(or away from it, depending on whether two north or two south poles are stuck to the battery),
produce a field pattern that sprays out all around the battery,
passing at right angles through the coil current.
So the force generated is at right angles to both the current and the outward (or inward) pointing flux.
The only direction that is at right angles to both of those direction is along the axis of the coil.
